2649.text: We don’t have to choose between a green military and an effective one. My plan will improve our service members’ readiness and safety, and achieve cost savings for American taxpayers. Together, we can fight climate change—and win.

2650.text: The Pentagon is the single largest government consumer of energy, and it’s dependent on fossil fuels. To improve military readiness and help us achieve a #GreenNewDeal, the Pentagon should achieve net zero carbon emissions for all its non-combat bases and infrastructure by 2030.

2651.text: Today, I am introducing my Defense Climate Resiliency and Readiness Act to harden the U.S. military against the threat posed by climate change, and to leverage its huge energy footprint as part of our climate solution. https://t.co/fYixnw11bz

2652.text: Senior military leaders have warned Congress of the national security challenge that climate change poses. The military is taking steps to become more energy efficient and resilient. But instead of meeting this threat head on, Washington is ignoring it—and making it worse.

2653.text: Climate change is real, it’s worsening by the day, and it’s undermining our military readiness. More and more, accomplishing the mission depends on our ability to continue operations in the face of floods, drought, wildfires, desertification, and extreme cold.

2654.text: RT @DrLeanaWen: This is the most extreme and dangerous policy since Roe vs. Wade, banning abortion at any point in pregnancy — going so far…

2655.text: This ban is dangerous and exceptionally cruel—and the bill’s authors want to use it to overturn Roe v. Wade. I've lived in that America and let me tell you: We are not going back—not now, not ever. We will fight this. And we will win. https://t.co/WNlr7Ys73q

2656.text: Because of greedy pharmaceutical companies pumping drugs into town, Kermit, WV got hit hard by the opioid epidemic. I went there last week to say: Enough. I have a plan to end the opioid crisis and hold the people who caused it accountable. https://t.co/IR4I4fUUG4

2662.text: I won’t do a town hall with Fox News because I won’t invite millions of Democratic primary voters to tune in, inflate ratings, and help sell ads for an outlet that profits from racism and hate. If you agree, sign our petition. https://t.co/zAyBN7i8Jf

2663.text: I’ve done 57 media avails and 131 interviews, taking over 1,100 questions from press just since January. Fox News is welcome to come to my events just like any other outlet. But a Fox News town hall adds money to the hate-for-profit machine. To which I say: hard pass.

2664.text: I’m running a campaign to reach all Americans. I take questions from the press and voters everywhere I go. I’ve already held town halls in 17 states and Puerto Rico—including WV, OH, GA, UT, TN, TX, CO, MS & AL.

2665.text: Here’s one place we can fight back: I won’t ask millions of Democratic primary voters to tune into an outlet that profits from racism and hate in order to see our candidates—especially when Fox will make even more money adding our valuable audience to their ratings numbers.

2666.text: But Fox News is struggling as more and more advertisers pull out of their hate-filled space. A Democratic town hall gives the Fox News sales team a way to tell potential sponsors it's safe to buy ads on Fox—no harm to their brand or reputation (spoiler: It’s not).

2667.text: Hate-for-profit works only if there’s profit, so Fox News balances a mix of bigotry, racism, and outright lies with enough legit journalism to make the claim to advertisers that it’s a reputable news outlet. It’s all about dragging in ad money—big ad money.

2668.text: Fox News is a hate-for-profit racket that gives a megaphone to racists and conspiracists—it’s designed to turn us against each other, risking life and death consequences, to provide cover for the corruption that’s rotting our government and hollowing out our middle class.

2669.text: I love town halls. I’ve done more than 70 since January, and I’m glad to have a television audience be a part of them. Fox News has invited me to do a town hall, but I’m turning them down—here’s why...

2670.text: Authoritarian tendencies. Gleefully undermining democracy. Corruption. No wonder Viktor Orbán was so warmly welcomed by Donald Trump yesterday. https://t.co/JellEw97pY

2671.text: Betsy DeVos is the worst Secretary of Education we’ve seen. Instead of championing our students, she protects for-profit colleges that break the law. So I’m making a pledge: In a Warren administration, the Secretary of Education will be a former public school teacher. https://t.co/fz4uiMQa7N

2672.text: I grew up on the ragged edge of the middle class. My family didn’t have money for a college application—let alone college. I dropped out of school at 19 to get married. My second chance was a commuter college that cost $50 a semester—and I hung on for dear life. https://t.co/wNbsweMzEd

2673.text: When pharmaceutical CEOs pad their pockets and commit criminal negligence while pushing drugs, they should go to jail. https://t.co/l26S1v1fdW

2674.text: Family farmers across the country are being squeezed by the Trump administration’s terrible policies. Our farmers deserve better. https://t.co/K0vP4KQlpq

2675.text: Feeling inspired after the #AFTVotes town hall this afternoon. I’ll always stand behind our teachers and their right to unionize. Thank you @AFTunion and @rweingarten for letting me be part of today’s powerful conversation. https://t.co/YMPkeMJZAc

2676.text: Thank you for the questions and powerful conversation about teaching in America. https://t.co/jpbY2N99YC

2677.text: We need a Secretary of Education who actually cares about our teachers and students. https://t.co/SHxWH7MuCm

2678.text: In my administration, the Secretary of Education will be a former public school teacher who is committed to public education. Add your name if you agree that we need to replace Betsy DeVos with someone who actually fights for our kids. https://t.co/wiqD1hpLmk

2679.text: The next Secretary of Education should be a former public school teacher—someone who will fight for students and not for shady, for-profit colleges. https://t.co/10KYDW6E5O

2680.text: I’ll be speaking at the #AFTVotes town hall about how we can level the playing field for America’s public school teachers. Tune in at 4:30 PM ET today. https://t.co/wkNfpMLiiX

2681.text: And we need to make it easier to join a union. Unions give teachers—and all workers—power in negotiations over the long run. That's good for teachers, good for students, and good for making sure we put the resources we need directly into our schools.

2682.text: My Secretary of Education will be someone with real teaching experience, who understands how low pay, tattered textbooks and crumbling classrooms affect educators and students. Someone who understands the crushing burden of student debt and will fight back.

2683.text: But Betsy DeVos is just a symptom of a badly broken system. We’re up against powerful forces, and to win, we need big structural change. So here’s my plan: Under a Warren administration, the Secretary of Education will be a public school teacher. https://t.co/4M33NGTNJt

2684.text: There's no greater example of how we're failing students and teachers than Betsy DeVos, the worst Secretary of Education we’ve seen. Appointed despite her conflicts of interest, she's spent her time protecting for-profit colleges that break the law and cheat students.

2685.text: America’s teachers are being crushed. Too many teachers are working multiple jobs, drowning in student debt, and struggling to teach on shoestring budgets and insulting salaries. America is failing our teachers—and when we fail our teachers, we fail our future.

2686.text: Ever since I was little, I wanted to be a teacher. My 2nd grade teacher, Mrs. Lee, was the first person to tell me that I could be a teacher too. And thanks to a high quality, public education, I did become a teacher. I want kids today to have the same opportunities I did.

2687.text: I want to make it clear during #MilitaryAppreciationMonth: Those who serve our country deserve a safe, affordable place to live—for themselves and their families. My plan to improve our military housing would protect families from abuse and hold private developers accountable. https://t.co/cwHLjhDQJB

2689.text: We’ve had over 70 town halls and we do a selfie line after each one. Not only is it fun, it’s when I get to listen to people’s stories. I’m so glad I got to take my 20,000th selfie yesterday with Umeirra in Cincinnati. https://t.co/5yQFAlc41A

2690.text: Black moms are dying from childbirth-related causes at rates 3-4 times higher than white moms—and structural racism is the root cause of this problem. We need to call it out, and then fight back. https://t.co/NQfVwgd87f

2691.text: On #MothersDay, I’m thinking about Black and Brown moms in our country. Women of color are dying from pregnancy and childbirth-related causes at staggering rates and it is the direct result of institutional and structural racism. We need to call it out and address it head on. https://t.co/fPVbAZSKzz

2692.text: My mother didn’t have much, but she knew that her kids had a fighting chance to build a future. Today, not every family has that fighting chance. That’s what I’m fighting for to honor my mother, on Mother’s Day and every day. https://t.co/DUi5ZcVI0h

2693.text: For a long time, I thought that was just a story about my mother. And then years later, I came to understand that it's a story about millions of Americans who—no matter how scared they are—reach down, dig deep, find it, and pull up what they need to take care of the family.

2694.text: I watched her while she pulled it together, put that dress on, put on her high heels, blew her nose, walked to Sears, and got a minimum wage job. And that minimum wage job saved our house, but more importantly, it saved our family. That story is written on my heart.

2695.text: Spread out on the bed was a black dress. It was that one dress that every mom had—it only came out for weddings, funerals, and graduations. She kept saying, “We will not lose this house. We will not lose this house.” She’d never worked outside the home, and she was terrified.

2696.text: Happy #MothersDay! Today, I’m honoring my mother. One morning after my daddy’s heart attack, I remember standing in their bedroom. Her face was red and puffy, with wadded-up tissues next to her. We’d just lost our family station wagon. Our house was next.

2697.text: Yay! Thanks for coming today and taking a selfie with me, Umeirra. https://t.co/RDEzjZqExY

2711.text: This crisis has been driven by greed, pure and simple, and it’s time to change that. I’ve got a plan to make these companies pay up to ensure every person gets the care they need. https://t.co/aNQkKWqKFf

2712.text: Here’s the truth: Fueling addiction is big business. The five companies being sued by Kermit earned $17 billion shipping prescription opioids to West Virginia during those few years, and their CEOs took home millions in bonuses and pay.

2713.text: This small but mighty town filed a lawsuit against the pharmacy and five of the wholesale drug distributors who exacerbated the crisis. And it’s just one of many similar lawsuits lodged by towns, counties, and states across the country.

2714.text: The companies shipping these pills repeatedly disregarded requirements to report suspicious patterns of behavior, and the state Board of Pharmacy failed to enforce its own rules. But Kermit is fighting back.

2715.text: Over a period of just a few years, this town of only 400 people was flooded with approximately 13 million prescription opioid pills— that’s more than 30,000 pills per resident—all delivered to a single local pharmacy .

2716.text: Today, I went to Kermit, a small town along the Kentucky-West Virginia border that’s been hard-hit by the opioid epidemic — and not by accident. I’ll tell you why.

2717.text: The opioid epidemic is crushing communities across the country. My plan to fix it, the #CAREact, would provide $100 billion in federal funding directly to communities like Bethlehem, NH. That’s what’s needed to make sure every single person gets the treatment they need. https://t.co/cVNKKHZJIV

2725.text: Bank lobbyists claimed that changing the bankruptcy rules for student loans would reduce costs. Instead, costs went up and private student lending exploded. It was great for banks and bad for students. Congress should pass our bill to change this law immediately.

2726.text: In 2005, Congress passed a bad bankruptcy bill that made it harder for working families to stay afloat—including by making it nearly impossible for people to get rid of student loans in bankruptcy. Today, @DickDurbin and I introduced a bill to change that.

2735.text: The #CAREact is modeled after the Ryan White CARE Act, which—after a long fight—provided significant funding to help communities combat the HIV/AIDS epidemic. We need that kind of big, structural change to tackle the opioid epidemic today. https://t.co/8yrfmr71c2

2736.text: Real, structural change to address the opioid epidemic is going to take new leadership in Washington. If you’re with me in the fight to end this crisis, add your name and become a citizen co-sponsor of the #CAREact. https://t.co/5EiSUdbBSK

2737.text: Nearly two decades into the 21st century—in the wealthiest country in the world—American life expectancy went down, and it’s largely driven by the opioid epidemic. The #CAREact gives us a fighting chance at ending the crisis and saving lives. https://t.co/QU9gf6yAdl

2743.text: Under my plan, billionaires that got rich off of this crisis would pay to help ensure every person gets the care they need. And under my Corporate Executive Accountability Act, executives who deliberately hurt people through criminal negligence will face real criminal penalties.

2744.text: That's a start. But this crisis has been driven by greed, pure and simple. To solve it, we need to hold business executives that cheat, defraud, and addict people accountable.

2745.text: The CARE Act also works to strengthen our addiction treatment infrastructure—demanding states use Medicaid to its fullest to tackle the crisis, expanding access to medication-assisted treatment, and ensuring treatment programs and recovery residences meet high standards.

2746.text: These resources would support the whole continuum of care, from early intervention, to harm reduction, to long-term support services. They would ensure access to mental health services and help provide critical wraparound services like housing support and medical transportation.

2747.text: Today, Rep. Cummings & I—along with 80+ cosponsors—are rolling out the CARE Act, a comprehensive plan to end the opioid crisis by providing states & communities $100 billion over the next 10 years to ensure every single person gets the treatment they need. https://t.co/aNQkKWqKFf

2748.text: 70,000 Americans died in 2017 from a drug overdose—the majority due to opioids. Emergency room visits for opioid overdoses are skyrocketing, and too many are still not receiving treatment. This is a public health crisis. And it has also severely impacted communities of color.

2749.text: Heartsick for the victims, their loved ones, and the Highlands Ranch community. How many more of our children’s schools must be torn apart by gun violence until Congress does something? We need gun reform. Now.

2751.text:
There are three inescapable facts from the Mueller report that Mitch McConnell can't hide:
1. A foreign government attacked our elections in order to help Donald Trump.
2. Trump welcomed that help.
3. Trump tried to obstruct the investigation into his actions.

2800.text: I missed Shannon on the first try, and then I saw her tweet asking to call her back—so I did. I’m deeply grateful for Shannon and her dedication to this grassroots movement. https://t.co/rqAGFxF7vj

2801.text: En Estados Unidos, se necesita un liderazgo que respete a todos sus ciudadanos—y en el caso de Puerto Rico, el respeto significa poner las vidas de millones de ciudadanos por encima de los márgenes de ganancia de Wall Street. https://t.co/AJ2jsQvW7r

2802.text: Puerto Rico shows us a clear example of how well the federal government works for Wall Street and how poorly it works for everyone else. I believe we should fight back—and treat Puerto Rico with respect. https://t.co/qHdQuFEgDX

2803.text: Crippling student loan debt is holding families back. My new plan would change that for Valerie from South Carolina, and millions of other Americans across the country. https://t.co/moa2MaxDZE

2804.text: Esta legislación establecería una avenida para el alivio comprensivo de la deuda de Puerto Rico. Puedes leer todos los detalles aquí. https://t.co/KnjIP2wpPM

2805.text: Los ejecutivos de Wall Street ven la desesperación en la isla como una oportunidad para obtener ganancias—y eso me da asco. Por eso estoy presentado nuevamente el Acta de Alivio para los Territorios Estadounidenses.

2806.text: El Congreso tuvo la oportunidad de romper con el control de Wall Street. En vez de hacerlo, aprobaron una legislación llamada PROMESA, estableciendo una junta de supervisión fiscal que exigió recortes a servicios básicos, coartando la posibilidad de recuperación para PR.

2807.text: Sin embargo, por causa de su estatus único, esas avenidas legales no están a su alcance. Gran parte de la deuda está en manos de Wall Street, quienes intentan exprimir hasta el último centavo de ganancia.

2808.text: Si Puerto Rico fuera una corporación grande o una ciudad en los Estados Unidos en este tipo de crisis financiera, podría declararse en bancarrota: pagando parte de su deuda, liquidando el resto y así comenzar a reconstruir.

2809.text: Los huracanes Irma y María devastaron a Puerto Rico y a los millones de ciudadanos estadounidenses que viven en la isla. Queda claro que la respuesta de la administración de Trump fue inefectiva, pero una de las mayores limitaciones frenando la recuperación recae en su deuda.

2810.text: Wall Street executives see the island’s desperation as just another opportunity to make a profit—and it makes me sick. That’s why I’m re-introducing the U.S. Territorial Relief Act to provide Puerto Rico with a path to comprehensive debt relief. https://t.co/dXxIVAVw21

2811.text: Much of Puerto Rico’s debt is held by Wall Street, which is trying to squeeze out every last penny of profit. Congress had a chance to break Wall Street's grip. Instead, they passed PROMESA, imposing an oversight board which has slashed services, hindering the recovery.

2812.text: If Puerto Rico were a big company or an American city in this kind of financial trouble, it could file for bankruptcy, pay some of its debts, discharge the rest, then start rebuilding. But because of its unique status, those legal options aren’t available.

2813.text: Hurricanes Irma and Maria devastated Puerto Rico and the millions of U.S. citizens who live there. The Trump Administration's response was slow and ineffective—but one of the biggest constraints holding back the recovery has been Puerto Rico's debt.

2814.text: My three big brothers served in the military: Don Reed and John joined the Air Force, and David joined the Army. I’m glad I got to talk with and listen to military families in Nevada on Saturday. They deserve better and you bet I’m going to keep fighting for them. https://t.co/aKllrG4HWp

2815.text: Hate has no place in our country. The threat of white nationalism is real. And when I'm president, the Justice Department will prosecute domestic terrorists to the full extent of the law.
